metadata.title: Herniated Disc
anatomical location body part affected: The lumbar spine including intervertebral discs
description: Lumbar disc herniation is an injury or weakness of the inner portion of a disc in the lower spine area. This causes it to slip and protrude, pressing on spinal nerves and causing pain(1,2,7)

M51.M51.0: lumbar and other intervertebral disc disorders with myelopathy

ICD-10 codes.M96.1: postlaminectomy syndrome, not elsewhere classified ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes

reimbursement: Reimbursement will depend on the patient’s insurance. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Approximately 30–40%  of persons with lumbar disc herniation are asymptomatic(3)

Signs and symptoms include:(2,4) –lower back pain –neck pain –pain in buttocks that may travel down thigh and calf –numbness or tingling in lower extremities –Leg weakness causing unstable gait –inability to lift arms or hold items  Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Patients in extreme pain that cannot be lessened by movement or changes in position need to be evaluated by a physician prior to initiation of therapy to rule out more serious pathology

Caution should be used during the evaluation to prevent exacerbation of symptoms. Additionally, any movement or other evaluation that causes pain that is centralized to peripheralized should be stopped immediately

Refer to physician if symptoms and clinical findings suggest myelopathy (i.e., clumsiness of upper or lower limbs, bilateral lower extremity weakness, urinary urgency, frequent falls, hyperreflexia, positive Babinski test)
Children and adolescents who report low back pain may have an underlying medical condition needing a referral to a physician

causes pathogenesis: Lumbar disc herniation occurs when tissue between vertebrae protrudes into the spinal canal, causing pressure on a spinalnerve(3,4,5)
Lumbar disc herniation is commonly a result of degeneration. With aging, discs are more prone to tear or rupture with aminor twist or strain to low back area (2,4,5)
Approximately 90% of lumbar disc herniations occur at L4-L5  and L5-S1  (3,4,6)
risk factors deyo, sommers: Risk factors for lumbar disc herniation in pediatric patients include:–participation in contact sports–genetics–scoliosis–physical trauma, such as a motor vehicle accident
Risk factors for lumbar disc herniation in adult patients include:–excess body weight–jobs with repetitive lifting, bending, pulling, and twisting at waist–genetics–tobacco/nicotine use

overall contraindications precautions: Lumbar disc herniation can cut off nerve impulses to lower back and legs, causing loss of bladder and bowel control. This is known as cauda equina syndrome and it may require emergency surgery (2)
Loss of sensation in inner thighs, back of legs, and around rectum is a long-term complication of lumbar disc herniation known as saddle anesthesia(2)

When using manipulation or mobilization, care should be taken to do a complete neurological examination as well as to rule out fracture, spondylolysis/listhesis, or other pathologies for which manipulation is contraindicated. Manipulation/ mobilization techniques should be performed only by skilled clinicians; if performed incorrectly, joint trauma or hypermobility may occur
Caution should be used during the evaluation to prevent exacerbation of symptoms. Additionally, any movement or other evaluation that causes pain to peripheralize should be stopped
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -When and how did symptoms begin? -Insidious onset vs. traumatic event? -What is the 24-hour  pattern of pain? -Damage to the disc may be associated with repetitive, prolonged flexion of the spine as well as extended postures (e.g., prolonged sitting)  -What positions/activities are aggravating? Alleviating?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Initial treatment guidelines for lumbar disc herniation commonly are conservative. Most patients respond to conservative treatment and surgical intervention is usually not necessary. Surgical treatment is recommended only if symptoms have not subsided in 46 weeks or pain becomes increasingly worse and debilitating When there is a poor response to conservative treatment and patient continues to have mildtomoderate pain, an epidural steroid injection might be considered, especially for radicular pain (1,6) Common surgical procedures for a lumbar disc herniation include discectomy, microdiscectomy, laminectomy, and spinal fusion (1,2,4)
course of treatment.medications: Medications for current illness/injury Analgesics (acetaminophen, opioids(6) NSAIDs to help reduce pain and inflammation in the acute phase of disc herniation(6)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  X-ray,  MRI, CT scan, discogram, myelogram, EMG (electromyogram), NCS (nerve conduction studies). CT scan or MRI is best for diagnosing a disc herniation(1,2)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) -What specific movements, positions, or tasks increase or decrease symptoms? -Inquire about the presence of increased symptoms with sit-to-stand, coughing, sneezing, or carrying objects -Pain may also increase gradually after prolonged periods of sitting or standing
history of present illness.body chart: Body chart -Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. The disc is aneural, so not all herniations produce symptoms. However, compression of a nerve root can elicit symptoms along the nerve root distribution. Symptoms can also occur from the disc protruding onto ligaments, dura mater, and blood vessels -With a lumbar herniated disc, the patient may complain of severe midline back pain that spreads across the back into the buttock and thigh. Large protrusions may cause signs of spinal cord injury (bladder dysfunction, saddle anesthesia) -In the thoracic region, symptoms may be centralized or wrap around the ribcage -Pain may be noted up to three segments above and below the herniation due to innervation patterns of the afferent nerves. Muscle guarding may be noted over multiple segmental levels
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Nature of symptoms -What symptoms are being experienced? -What symptoms were experienced initially? -Is pain localized or generalized? -Description of pain (burning, aching, stabbing)? -Extremity weakness? -Have there been any occurrences of paresis of any extremities? -Is the patient experiencing any paresthesias; if so, in what areas? -Is the patient experiencing any saddle paresthesia or numbness? -Bowel/bladder difficulty?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables. Inquire about changes in symptoms throughout the day and night
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings per night. Inquire about sleep position and if patient finds a position that is without pain
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)  Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe ____________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Other current or previous spinal disorders? Any neuromuscular disorder? Any other pertinent medical history?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient’s job involve prolonged postures in sitting or standing, heavy lifting, or repetitive motion?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Inquire about limitations in ADLs -What activities is the patient having difficulty with? -Gait or other functional deficits?
social and occupational history.living environment: Inquire about stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: May want to consider height and weight measurements, if pertinent. May also want to assess for a leg-length  discrepancy if a lumbar herniated disc is suspected
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess for need, appropriate fit, appropriate use. May require cane or walker if in severe pain, especially lower extremity radicular pain
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess balance statically and dynamically. Decreased balance, difficulty turning, increased base of support, and other deficits are not typically observed. Pain accompanied by trunk co-contraction  might affect balance. If present, symptoms may be associated with a cervical myelopathy, and the patient should be referred back to the referring physician
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Although they typically are normal, assessment of the distal pulses (e.g., radial artery, tibial artery, dorsalis pedis artery) may be appropriate if vascular claudication is suspectedSee Special tests specific to diagnosis , below Ergonomics/body mechanics –Assess for appropriate lifting technique (depending on severity), transfer technique (i.e., log rolling sit to supine and vice versa) –For additional information on ergonomics, see  Clinical Review ... Ergonomics Assessment and Intervention  ; CINAHLT708456 Functional mobility  (including transfers, etc.) –Oswestry Disability Index –FIM –SF-36
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess for the presence of antalgia or abnormalities due to pain or weakness and determine if there is a need for an assistive deviceConsider the possibility of nonspinal causes of pain, even in patients who present with a specific diagnosis of disc herniation –Assess lumbar and thoracic passive accessory intervertebral movements (PAIVMs). Identify each segment as hypermobile, hypomobile, or normal –Assess sacroiliac (SI) and hip joints
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Manual muscle test trunk and extremities. Patient may have myotomal weakness –To check the lower extremity myotomes (lumbar herniation)  -Hip flexion (L1-L2) -Knee extension (L3-4) -Ankle dorsiflexion (L4-5) -First toe extension (L5) -Ankle plantarflexion (S1-2)
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess for the presence of -vertebral hyper-  or hypomobility -spondylolisthesis/lysis -muscle spasm
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Assess in standing/sitting for -abnormal lordosis -inappropriate pelvic tilt -decreased lumbar lordosis -lateral shifting -forward head posture -internally rotated shoulders -kyphosis -scoliosis -height symmetry of joints and anatomical landmarks
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess trunk and extremity flexibility; determine if muscular tightness or pain restricts trunk ROM. Assess cautiously within the patient’s pain tolerance. Note Gowers’ sign if present
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess for neurological abnormality. Patient may have hyporeflexia if there is peripheral nerve impingement and hyperreflexia if there is spinal cord impingement –To check the lower extremity reflexes (lumbar herniation) -Patellar (L3-4) -Achilles (S1)Assess safety and ability during performance of work duties and leisure activities –The Oswestry Disability Index may be used to assess disability during daily living activities
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –Sensation testing should include light touch, deep pressure, temperature, two-point  discrimination, and any other sensation testing deemed relevant based on the patient’s history –To check the lower extremity dermatomes (lumbar herniation) -Inguinal area (L1) -Proximal anterior thigh (L2) -Distal anterior thigh (L3) -Medial lower leg (L4) -Lateral lower leg (L5) -Posterior calf (S1)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Assess cautiously and within the patient’s pain tolerance –Straight leg raise (SLR) test(8) -While the patient is supine and both knees are straight, the symptomatic leg is slowly raised (hip flexion) while maintaining knee extension until symptoms are experienced -The leg is then lowered until symptoms subside -If symptoms return when the ankle is dorsiflexed, the test is positive –Slump test(8) -This test is a series of steps that are continued unless symptoms arise -While sitting on the edge of an examination table, the patient slowly slumps forward while keeping the head in neutral -The patient then slowly flexes the neck and the examiner holds the patient in this position -The knee is then slowly extended  -If there are still no symptoms present, the ankle is dorsiflexed by examiner -A positive test is the reproduction of symptoms with any of the steps, which are then alleviated with cervical extension

contraindications precautions: centralization of pain does not occur with changes in position or with movement
saddle anesthesia or bladder dysfunction is present (indicative of spinal cord involvement or cauda equina syndrome)
the patient is in extreme pain
the medical condition contraindicates the maneuver during treatment (e.g., spinal stenosis, spondylolisthesis)
Acute cervical trauma, including whiplash-associated  disorders
Use of steroids or other medications that tend to compromise bone integrity
Rheumatologic disorders affecting connective tissue, including rheumatoid arthritis and ankylosing spondylitis
Patients with COPD or other respiratory disorders
Over an area of circulatory compromise
Over an area of peripheral vascular disease
Avoid applying cold over superficial nerves
Over an area of poor sensation
In the very young or very old
Application over areas with a lack of intact thermal sensation
Application over areas of vascular insufficiency or vascular disease
Application over areas of recent hemorrhage or potential hemorrhage
Application over areas of known malignancy
Application over areas of acute inflammation
Application over infected areas where infection may spread or cross-contamination  may occur
Application over areas where liniments or heat rubs have recently been applied

Electrodes should not be placed over: -the trunk or heart region in patients with demand-type  pacemakers or implantable cardioverter defibrillators -the pelvic, abdominal, lumbar, or hip region in pregnant women -carotid bodies -phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators -areas of known peripheral vascular disease, including arterial or venous thrombosis or thrombophlebitis -the phrenic nerve, eyes, or gonads -areas of active osteomyelitis -areas of hemorrhage

Electrotherapy should be used with caution -in patients without intact sensation -in patients who are unable to communicate -in patients with compromised mental status -in patients with cardiac dysfunction -in patients with epilepsy
Electrodes should not be placed -over neoplasms -over compromised skin -over tissues vulnerable to hemorrhage or hematoma -over the cervical or craniofacial region
Pregnancy—over the abdomen or low back
Active bone growth at the epiphysis
Cancer—over a known or suspected area of malignancy

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Treatment is required if there is pain, weakness, decreased ROM/flexibility, decreased function, poor posture, and/or faulty body mechanics. Physical therapy may also be indicated after interventions for disc herniation such as microdiscectomy, percutaneous discectomy, open discectomy, fusion, or intradiscal electrothermal therapy Based on a 2015 systematic literature review and longitudinal study, recurrent back pain after discectomy for herniated disc was present in 15–25%  of patients at the 2-year  follow-up(12)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Sacroiliac joint pain Zygapophyseal joint pain Discogenic pain Piriformis syndrome Spondylolisthesis Lumbosacral plexopathy Lumbar spinal stenosis Cervical myelopathy Shoulder pathology Hip pathology
prognosis: Based on the results of a 2015 systematic review of spontaneous disc regression and type of lumbar herniated disc, the authors concluded that patients with disc sequestration(96%) and disc extrusion (70%) had a higher possibility of spontaneous regression than patients with protruding discs (40%) or bulging discs (13%)(13)

Researchers in Austria followed up 12 years later on the effects of postoperative physical therapy (PT), started one week after lumbar disc surgery, and found that patients who participated in PT had greater long-term  health benefits than those with no intervention, but their results were not better when compared to patients who participated in sham PT(14) –Based on an RCT involving 111 patients following first-time,  uncomplicated lumbar disc surgery –PT was 20 treatment sessions over a 12-week  period that was customized by physician and physical therapist; sham PT consisted of 20 sessions of neck massage, and the control group was told to “wait and see” for the first 3 months –Outcome measure was changes in ratings on the Low Back Pain Rating Scale
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Physical therapist trained in manual therapy for graded joint mobilization (high velocity, low amplitude thrust) Psychiatry, psychology, occupational therapy, or social services for depression-related  issues
treatment summary: A prescribed physical therapy program will include(11,15) –deep tissue massage –hot and cold therapy –electrical stimulation –core-stabilizing  exercises –stretching and flexibility exercises –hydrotherapy –traction –spinal manipulation, such as oblique-pulling  manipulation

Authors of a 2014 Cochrane Review of rehabilitation after surgery for herniation of the lumbar disc that included 22 RCTs and 2,503 patients concluded that(15) –patients in exercise programs started 4–6 weeks post-surgery  reported slightly less pain and disability than those who received no treatment –patients who participated in high-intensity  exercise programs reported slightly less pain and disability than those who participated in low-intensity  exercise programs –the authors suggested that no firm conclusions could be drawn due to the low quality of evidence

Vertebral resonant oscillation using the POLD technique may be an effective manual therapy approach for reducing the severity and radiation of pain in patients with lumbar disc hernia with sciatica(16) –Based on an RCT conducted in Spain on 30 patients –The control group received microwave thermotherapy, TENS, and ultrasound treatment and did self-directed  muscle stretching. The intervention group received vertebral resonant oscillation using the POLD technique. Both groups received a total of nine sessions –When compared to the control group, patients in the intervention group were found to have -significant improvements in forward flexion -a significant reduction in the severity of pain (V AS scale) -a significant reduction in pain extension (centralization phenomena) . desired outcomes with associated outcome: Decreased pain and muscle guarding–V AS
Increased ROM to prior level of function–Goniometry
Increased strength to prior level of function–Manual muscle and myotomal testing
Improved posture and body mechanics–Posture assessment
Improved gait/function–Gait assessment, functional testing (Oswestry Disability Index, FIM, SF-36)

maintenance or prevention: Appropriate body mechanics during lifting and other strenuous activity
Home exercise program with concentration on trunk/core strengthening
Neutral sitting posture and appropriate work ergonomics
